description: A program by Phil Donahue about human beings exploring why humans act in certain ways and whether people can change their behaviors. Themes of the program include gender roles, the family, education, and marriage. The program begins with a discussion of the biological differences between men and women and an interview with Dr. June Reinisch of the Kinsey Institute. The program continues with a discussion of the differences between men and women's brains and cognitive ability. Part two focuses on the role of marriage and the family in society. description: Karen DeCrow and Phyllis Schlafly debate the Equal Rights Amendment at the University of Tulsa. The debate was sponsored by the Student Association of the University of Tulsa. Schlafly presents her argument first and then DeCrow speaks. Questions are taken from the audience. The attempted passing of the ERA was a decade-long process. After the amendment was approved in the United States Senate in 1972, it went to the states for ratification. NOW was heavily involved in campaigning for ratification, though eventually only 35 of the required 38 states would ratify by the 1982 deadline (already extended once) and the amendment failed. During this time, one voice that loudly dissented with the women’s liberation movement was Phyllis Schlafly with her STOP ERA campaign. DeCrow and Schlafly had completely opposite viewpoints, but enjoyed each other’s company. They toured the country together, debating the ERA over 80 times.

description: WWWE radio 11 of Cleveland, Ohio broadcast. After the local news report, Merle Pollis interviews Karen DeCrow about an upcoming vote in Ohio to restrict the sale of pornography in stores like Lawson's. DeCrow shares her stance that this is a threat to the First Amendment. Lawson's was later sued by the American Family Association, after a Dairy Mart manager in Ohio complained that the company's policy of selling pornography subjected her to sexual and religious harassment. The court case, Stanley v. Lawson Co., was seen as a test of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. The court ultimately ruled in favor of Lawson.

description: Karen DeCrow and Phyllis Schlafly debate the Equal Rights Amendment on the televised program called Richard Hogue Weekdays. Hogue structures the debate around the topics of education, government power, military, employment, and family. The attempted passing of the ERA was a decade-long process. After the amendment was approved in the United States Senate in 1972, it went to the states for ratification. NOW was heavily involved in campaigning for ratification, though eventually only 35 of the required 38 states would ratify by the 1982 deadline (already extended once) and the amendment failed. During this time, one voice that loudly dissented with the women’s liberation movement was Phyllis Schlafly with her STOP ERA campaign. DeCrow and Schlafly had completely opposite viewpoints, but enjoyed each other’s company. They toured the country together, debating the ERA over 80 times.

description: Karen DeCrow's 49th birthday party. Guests representing various committees report on plans for DeCrow's 50th birthday celebration, a play on DeCrow's meetings as president of the National Organization for Women (NOW). DeCrow was elected the fourth president of NOW in 1974. She served two terms, getting re-elected under a Majority Caucus platform in 1975, which emphasized support for all women, including women of color and non-heterosexual women, as well as advocating for repeal of anti-abortion laws. As president, DeCrow raised public awareness of NOW further by being the organization’s first president to be invited to the White House. NOW under DeCrow’s presidency led boycotts against states that chose not to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment (ERA), helped defeat proposed limits on Title IX, held the first “Take Back the Night” march against violence against women, started multiple task forces, settled major employment discrimination lawsuits, and more.
